text: hello everyone in this video I will
demonstrate Amazon guard Duty ec2
runtime monitoring to show you how this
feature deepens threat detection
coverage for Amazon elastic compute
Cloud also simply known as Amazon
ec2 let's get
started a brief look at how this works
Amazon guard duty is a threat detection
service that continuously monitors your
AWS account and workloads for malicious
activities and deliver detailed security
findings for visibility and
Remediation E2 runtime monitoring
expands threat detection coverage for
ec2 instances at runtime and complement
the anomaly detection that Amazon G Duty
already provides by continuously
monitoring VPC flow logs DNS query logs
and AWS cloud trail management events
you now have visibility into on host
operating system level activities and
container level context into detected
threats easy to runtime monitoring
complements runtime coverage already
available for Amazon elastic kubernetes
service and Amazon elastic container
service on AWS fargate
giving you comprehensive runtime
visibility and detection across popular
AWS compute
Services let us now navigate to the G
Duty service to see this feature in
action in the
AWS Management
console search and select G Duty
service it's important to note that you
need to enable G Duty in order to enable
runtime monitoring and to help you get
started G Duty has a 30-day free trial
per account per region for those who are
using G Duty for the first time you can
enable G Duty and runtime monitoring on
a single account or in an AWS
organization in an AWS organization you
can centrally enable runtime thread
detection coverage for accounts and
workloads across the organization using
AWS organizations to simplify your
security coverage and this is what it
would look
like on the left navigation pane under
protection
plan right there select runtime
monitoring under runtime monitoring
configuration on the configurations tab
select edit
with a few steps you can enable G Duty
easy to runtime monitoring in the G Duty
console and for your first time use you
need to enable runtime
monitoring any customer with AWS
accounts that have never tried easy to
runtime monitoring can try it for free
for 30 days and gain access to all
features and detection findings the gut
Duty consoles shows how many days are
left in the free trial and shows you
usage and
cost under the runtime monitoring
configuration scroll down to automated
agent configuration Amazon
ac2 now you can set up the G Duty
security agent for the individual ec2
instance for which you want to monitor
the runtime behavor
you can choose to deploy G Duty security
agent either
automatically or
manually now let's see how this looks
like in a single
account in a single
account we can enable easy to runtime
monitoring by going
to runtime monitoring under protection
plan
under
configurations enable runtime
monitoring
confirm and then scroll all the way down
to Amazon
ec2 and enable automated agent
configuration for Amazon
ec2 when you enable E2 runtime
monitoring you can find the covered ec2
instance list account ID and coverage
status and whether the agent is able to
receive runtime events from the
corresponding resource in the ec2
instance runtime
coverage even when the coverage status
is unhealthy meaning it is not currently
able to receive runtime findings you can
still have defense in-depth for your ec2
instance G Duty continues to provide
threat detection to the ec2 instance by
monitoring cloud trail VPC flow and DNS
logs that are associated with it one
thing that is important to note here is
that the agent will be deployed on the
ec2
instances with AWS systems
manager and it will use your Amazon VPC
endpoint to receive the runtime events
associated with your resources here's
the cool part guard Duty takes care of
this for you so you don't have to do it
manually if we head to the E2 instance
runtime coverage we will be provided by
the details of the instance that
are being monitored the account where
they
located the health status
and the agent management type we also
get to see the version of the agent and
we can see how long ago this was
updated next we are going to simulate a
gut Duty E2 runtime monitoring finding
from an ec2 instance by querying a
domain name that is associated with a
known command and control
server let's jump into the E2 instance
and see this in
action from our demo
instance I'm going to connect to it
using sessions manager and then I will
go ahead and run a dig
command and that's it now let's go back
to the G Duty findings and see see what
we have when guty detects potential
threats it generates security findings
and you can view the details of the
health
information from findings in the left
pen we can see our generated finding
from the
simulation the severity and details of
the finding differ based on the resource
role which indicates whether the ec2
resource was the target of the
suspicious activity or the actor
performing the
activity currently G Duty supports over
30 runtime security findings for ec2
instances such as detecting abused
domains backd do cryptocurrency related
activity and an authorized
communication we can choose the E2
instance finding to know more details we
can find all the information associated
with the findings and examine the
resources in question to determine if it
is behaving in an expected
manner if the activity is authorized
what we could do is we could use
suppression rules or trusted IP list to
prevent false positive notification for
that
resource you can integrate G Duty ec2
runtime monitoring with other AWS
services such as AWS security Hub or
Amazon detective and you can use Amazon
event Bridge allowing you to use
Integrations with security event
management or workflow systems such as
plank jira service now or trigger
automated and semi-automated responses
such as isolating the workload for
investigation and that's it in this
video we looked at how to enable gut
duties ec2 runtime monitoring we enabled
automated agent configuration which is a
preferred option for most customers as
it allows G duty to manage the security
agent on their behalf we simulated a g
Duty runtime monitoring finding from an
is2 instance by querying a domain name
that is associated with a known command
and control server to learn more on
runtime
monitoring follow the link in the
description
below thank you for watching and happy
